TitleMessage:
Open treatment of extra-articular distal radius fracture(Tri-Mal) 

(CPT 00000)

SectionList.Message:
Surgical Indication: 

- Presence of unstable morties (>4-5mm widening) on static or stress view
- Presence of talar shift on static or stress view

Room Prep: 

1)Thigh Tourniquet
2)Ipsilateral hip bump
3)Bump under ankle
4)Sterile prep and drape

Make longitudinal incision along the posterior margin of the fibula

Center incision over the fracture site

Anticipate the position of the superficial peroneal nerve crossing from the lateral to anterior compartments. 

Perform a superficial dissection through the skin subdermal layer.
Incise through the peroneal tendon sheath longitudinally and elevate peroneal muscle proximally with periosteal elevator.
Expose and open fracture site with free elevator.
Debride fracture with curette and rongeur.

Anticipate the position of the lag screw.

Placement should be perpendicular to the fracture line.

Use Hohmann retractor to widen opening.

Expand Weitlaner retractors to hold.

Place drill sleeve perpendicular to fracture line.

Place 3.5mm drill bit info 3.5mm drill sleeve. Drill first cortex.

Insert 2.5mm sleeve into the drilled hole and drill far cortex with 2.5mm.

Can countersink first cortex to increase surface area distribution for screw. 

Use depth gauge to measure length for appropriate screw size.

Insert lag screw and hand-tighten carefully to not break bone.

Remove bone reduction forceps.

Select appropriate plate.

Use plate benders to shape plate to the natural contour of the bone.

Hold plate in place with bone reduction forceps.

Plan out placement of 3 bicortical and 2 unicortical screws.

Using the sleeve as a guide tap with 2.5mm drill bit.

Measure depth and select appropriate screws.

Insert screws. Repeat in order for the remaining screws.
Wound closure in layers including peroneal tendon sheath, subdermal and dermal layers.

MessageList.Message:
Room Preparation:
1. Thigh Tourniquet(optional)
2. Ipsilateral hip bump to allow toes point straight up
3. Sterile prep and drape
Mark incision centered over the medial malleolus fracture.
Incision through skin with scalpel
Saphenous nerve and vein are within proximity anteriorly. They are protected with, anterior retraction of the subdermal tissue.
Incise through periosteum and expose fracture site. Perform limited periosteal elevation.
Gently gap over the fracture with freer elevator and removed interposed periosteum between the fracture. Gently debride fracture edges with curette.

Inspect medial talus and ankle joint through the gapped fracture for loose bodies and tibiotalar osteochondral defects. Inspect the posterior tibialis tendon posterior to the fracture site for injury.
After satisfactory debridement, irrigation with bulb syringe.

For fracture reduction, use 2.5mm drill bit and create a unicortical hole approximately 2cm proximal to the center of the fracture. Clamp the fracture with pointed reduction forceps and perform gentle reduction.
Confirm fracture reduction visually and fluoroscopically.
Insert two parallel K wires across the fracture site for cannulated screw fixation.
Confirm K wire position with fluoroscopy.
Drill over the K wire with cannulated drill unicortically.
Measure screw length with depth gauge over K wire. Place cannulated screw over K wire.
Repeat process for the 2nd screw. Remove K wires, reduction forceps, and retractors.
Confirm fracture reduction and hardware placement fluoroscopically.

Assess syndesmosis with external rotation stress test fluoroscopically. Widening of the medial mortise and syndesmosis upon external rotation in neutral plantarflexion demonstrates syndesmosis injury.
Irrigation with bulb syringe
If syndesmosis is stable, then perform wound closure in layers.

1. Well padded tourniquet on the upper arm
2. Supine with shoulder at the end of surgical bed centered on the hand table
3. Turn the bed 90 deg so the operating limb is directly away from the anesthesiologist
4. Optional bump under the wrist
5. Sterile prep and drape
Review preoperative XR which demonstrated loss of radial height, radial inclination and volar tilt that meets operative indication.
Identify the location of flexor carpi radialis tendon(FCR) with palpation.
Be mindful of the presence or absence of palmaris longus tendon(PL).
Mark incision along FCR tendon.
Use scalpel to sharply incise through the dermis layer and subdermal layer.
Expose FCR tendon sheath along entire length of the incision with utilization of dull-ended weitlaner retractors.
Gently incise FCR tendon sheath volarly.

Be mindful of palmar cutaneous branch of median nerve, which is ulnar to the FCR tendon.
This structure is usually not visualized, but it is protected with ulnar retraction of the FCR tendon.
Retract FCR tendon ulnarly and exposed the dorsal FCR tendon sheath.
Incise the dorsal FCR tendon sheath and expose the flexor pollicis longus tendon/muscle(FPL) through blunt dissection.
Be mindful of radial artery under the brachioradialis muscle(BR). Ligate small cross branches of the radial artery as needed prior to retraction.
Retract FPL ulnarly and BR medially with dull ended weitlaner retractors.
Expose pronator quadratus muscle(PQ), which spans the volar surface of the distal radius. Sharply make a “L” shaped incised through the distal and radial border of PQ.
Elevate the PQ from the radius with periosteal elevator and expose the fracture underneath.
Careful debridement of the fracture surface with freer and periosteal Elevator. Gap over the fracture using freer and remove interposed periosteum using rongeur.

Inspect the following:
     - Fracture pattern 
     - Comminution 
     - Bone quality
Irrigate with bulb syringe.
Reduction maneuver achieved with manual manipulation consists of axial traction, volar translation, and ulnar deviation of the hand.
Optional small roll of blue towel can be placed under the wrist to help maintain reduction.
Fluoroscopic confirmation of reduction with orthogonal views.
Insert K wire from the radial styloid obliquely across the fracture to temporarily maintain reduction.
Fluoroscopic confirmation of Kwire position with orthogonal views.
Place the appropriate chosen distal radius plate on the volar surface of the distal radius.
Check plate placement radially and ulnarly.
Drill (2.5mm) bicortically through the center of the proximal oval hole.
Use depth gauge to obtain approximate screw length.
Place a 3.5mm bicortical non-locking screw in the center of the proximal oval hole.
Obtain fluoroscopic views and check proximal and distal position of the plate.The distal end of the plate should not past the volar critical line.
The screws should be directly as distal as possible for subchondral support.
Insert distal non-locking cortical screw through the distal ulnar hole, which minimizes the risk of EPL injury during bicortical drilling.
Obtain orthogonal fluoroscopic views.
Insert locking screws of the distal row.
Obtain orthogonal fluoroscopic views for review.
Insert non-locking screws proximally.
Replace distal non-locking screw with locking screw.
Remove K wire.
Final fluoroscopic orthogonal views. Check forearm supination and pronation for distal radial ulnar joint instability.
Irrigation.
PQ attachment
Wound closure
